replyContent: Hi Jessica, thanks for the update & the extra star. We totally understand the need to receive everything you need from within the app. Currently, we are partnering with JHU & they are only updating the data twice a week. We are hopeful that this can be updated more frequently in a future release. This feedback has been shared with our team.

content: After a positive test, my partner contacted local health department and notified them, they didn't know anything MI COVID or a PIN. 3 days later a contact tracer called my partner to report a positive test, this tracer also claimed no knowledge of a PIN or the MI COVID app. It took another 68 hours for contact tracers to call me and let me know that I had been exposed (someone I share a bed with), I had been quarantining for 6 days at this point, app is good - MDHHS utilization terrible.
replyContent: So sorry to hear about the troubles you are experiencing with the app and receiving a PIN. Could you please provide the local health department info you were trying to contact for the PIN. Please provide this info to our customer support team at mdhhs-micovidalert@michigan.gov so we can troubleshoot this further.

content: Pointless app as it relies on a PIN number to report a positive status, but you can't get this PIN without calling the hotline, which is limited to business hours. When they finally do open, you'll spend more than 20 minutes trying to navigate the automated attendant system, only to spend more time on hold waiting for a representative. I never managed to get through, uninstalled the app.
replyContent: Thank you for your feedback. We’re sorry to hear about your experience receiving a PIN. As cases are increasing rapidly, its becoming more difficult for case investigators to reach every person following their positive test result in a timely matter. We appreciate your patience and perseverance in reporting a positive test result.

content: Good idea, but doesn't work in practice. I got covid, and when I tried to send an alert, it required a key from the health department. replyContent: To get your PIN, call your local health department first. You can also request a PIN through the MI COVID-19 hotline by dialing 2-1-1 or 888-535-6136. https://www.michigan.gov/mdhhs/0,5885,7-339-73970_5461_74040---,00.html

content: I'm positive and can't record it. I've had my rapid results for 5 days and send out results for 3 days, but can't report anything without a code from the health department. replyContent: We sincerely apologize for the inconvenience of not receiving a PIN. Case numbers have increased substantially over the past few weeks and we have updated the process for getting a PIN. You can also request a PIN through the MI COVID-19 hotline by dialing 2-1-1 or 888-535-6136. https://www.michigan.gov/mdhhs/0,5885,7-339-73970_5461_74040---,00.html

replyContent: This app is not a real-time app. Using the app shouldn’t make a difference to your phone's battery life. The app uses Bluetooth Low Energy. This is the same technology used by smartwatches/wireless earphones. The app checks for new exposures every 2 hours. If you go to Settings > Device Care -> Battery Charging you can optimize battery performance.

replyContent: With every new app version we are introducing new features and improving existing ones. We are sure that your feedback will only help us improve further.

replyContent: You are correct, the app depends solely on voluntary engagement for the success of slowing the spread of COVID-19. Unfortunately, not everyone that has the app is willing to share a positive test result. The following link explains the app's use of data and privacy: https://www.michigan.gov/coronavirus/0,9753,7-406-99891_102592_102596---,00.html

content: Yes happy to have this
So...what if I falsely report myself as having recieved a positive result and I walk around all over town all week?
replyContent: If a user tests positive for COVID-19, they may choose to notify other app users who may have had close contact with them. A user who tests positive for COVID-19 must enter a valid, 8-digit PIN provided by their public health contact tracer. This PIN is generated by public health & only used to enter a positive diagnosis in the MI COVID Alert app.

content: doesn't update - ever - CDC data page is from the day I downloaded the app a month ago - cases have changed dramatically, but app displays very old data
replyContent: On the stats page under United States/Michigan, there is a link for more info: https://coronavirus.jhu.edu/. This will give you the most updated data from the latest download of critical data on COVID-19 from the last 24 hours.

Simple and unobtrusive. When you install it doesn't make any requests for your GPS data so you know it's not tracking your location or anything. There's a chat interface to ask questions to someone at the health department.

I am excited to see an app for Michigan finally available and even though I am not in the Ingham County area I wanted to check it out. I like the addition of the stats from Johns Hopkins and the added use of pins with MDHS in order for someone to list themselves as having Covid. While I did not give it 5 stars (due to just getting the app) I did want to comment and let you know that I appreaciate it.
